repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

did.langmaterial: Materials are in primarily in English with some Spanish.
did.abstract: The Tamiment Library Labor Unions and Organizations (U.S.) Web Collection was created with the Web Archiving Service from the California Digital Library. The collection contains periodically archived websites of New York City metropolitan area Labor Unions, especially those whose records are held by the Tamiment Library's Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives (designated by the New York City Central Labor Council as the official repository for their member unions' records), websites of selected national labor unions, and websites of labor movement related organizations, e.g. organizations that support the goals/activity of organized labor and social and economic justice for working people, and websites that promote democracy within labor unions. Web archiving is an evolving practice, please be patient if sites do not display accurately.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Websites are directly captured from the website's respective source.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Tamiment Library Labor Unions and Organizations Web Collection, first began in 2007, contains websites of local New York and national labor unions, especially those whose records are held by the Tamiment Library's Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives (designated by the New York City Central Labor Council as the official repository for their member unions' records). The collection also contains websites of labor movement related organizations, e.g. organizations that support the goals/activity of organized labor and social and economic justice for working people; and websites that promote democracy within labor unions. Some of these organizations are multi-issue organizations, besides labor activism, some organizations work for women's rights, environmental causes, and labor history and education. These websites contain a huge variety of media, which include YouTube videos, pdfs, blog postings (including Tumblr and Wordpress blogs), petitions, news feeds, audio, and other media. These websites often act to document and update upon the organizations’ activities, schedule upcoming events, build awareness of their causes, or other media. Most websites are captured quarterly, but during periods of rapid update, the website are captured weekly or monthly. The links in the container list take the user to the main Web Archiving Service (WAS) page for each website, which contain more detailed description of each website.

The web collection documents the publicly available content of the web page, it does not archive material that is password protected or blocked due to robot txt exclusions. Although attempts are made to completely archive the entirety of a website, linked pages are often not captured, as can be pages within the host URL.

The types of materials in the web collection--publications, news listings, leaflets, and other materials that publicize events and activities--were formerly collected in analog form by Tamiment librarians and archivists are increasingly being published online. Therefore, it is important to capture these websites to document the activities of these unions and organizations.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Tamiment Library, New York University, a special collection documenting the history of United States radicalism, labor, and progressive social action, began web archiving in 2007 as part of a grant given by the National Digital Information Infrastructure and Preservation Program (NDIPP) of the Library of Congress, as part of a project to preserve born-digital political communication. As most unions, left movements, progressive organizations, and others stop creating ephemeral material and paper based collections and move most of their administrative and informational material to the web, Tamiment felt the need to continue to document the changing face of the labor and left movement into the web era. Tamiment uses the California Digital Library’s Web Archiving Service (WAS) as their tool to capture and preserve websites. WAS was created in 2007 and Tamiment is one of its earliest partners. The California Digital Library hosts the storage and infrastructure to the project. This service employs open source web archiving utilities developed by Internet Archive with the support of the The International Internet Preservation Consortium.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Tamiment Library and WAS operate in observance with Section 108 Study Group’s Report on Web Archiving. Tamiment archives websites for preservation and research purposes only. Tamiment does not hold the copyright to the websites. Researchers must contact the websites' owners to publish materials.

Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the: Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives Elmer Holmes Bobst Library 70 Washington Square South New York, NY 10012 Phone: (212) 998-2630 Fax: (212) 995-4225 E-mail: tamiment.wagner@library.nyu.edu

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: "Page Title." Archived month/day/year. Tamiment Library Labor Unions and Organizations Web Collection, Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University. ArchivalURL. (Accessed month/day/year).

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Archived websites are open to researchers without restrictions. Archived websites are made publically available 6 months after initial capture. Access to the websites can be found by clicking directly on the links in the container list or visiting the public page.

odd.head: Take Down Policy
odd.p: Tamiment respects robot txt exclusions and requests from websites with robot txt exclusions to allow our crawler to capture their website. Tamiment will also honor the website owner’s request to remove their website from the collection.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note
phystech.p: Due to technical or privacy issues, archived websites may not be exact copies of the original website at the time of the web crawl. This can include missing video or image files, the website could display as an index, or a number of different display issues. Tamiment's web archives are stored on an external service and can be slow to load, please be patient. Searching capabilities are available on the archives main page, which can be found here.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Tamiment Library uses the California Digital Library’s Web Archiving Service (WAS) to capture websites for historical purposes. WAS is a subscription service and provides a storage infrastructure and technical assistance, while Tamiment archivists select websites for capture based on Tamiment’s collecting policy. After websites have been selected, the archivist determines the collection/project the website falls into. After the site is added, the title of the site is sometimes changed to better reflect the name of the organization/project/event/site. Sites are crawled by what are commonly known as spiders, robots, or crawlers to index the website. WAS uses a crawler called Heritrix. These crawlers “capture” the website at a certain moment in time. Sites are captured for up to 36 hours and the host page only. The first capture and sometimes yearly captures are set to capture the host page and the linked pages, which will travel up to twenty-five pages from its host page. Websites are crawled quarterly, unless contemporary events cause rapid change to content on a website. This is an assembled collection, websites are chosen by the archivists. The archivist describes each site using subject headings, a brief description of the site and its contents, and tags. WAS arranges the websites alphabetically and preserves the websites.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: United Healthcare Workers East (1199SEIU), founded in 1932 as the Local 1199, is a local union of the Service Employees International Union, representing more than 300,000 members. Members work in homecare, hospital and nursing home industries, as well as pharmacies, freestanding clinics, and other healthcare settings. The mission of the union is to improve and expand quality patient care, to protect and improve the lives of members and their families, and to work in solidarity with working people in SEIU’s communities and around the world. In 1998, they affiliated to the Service Employees International Union (SEIU). Since 1998, 15 healthcare local unions throughout New York State, New Jersey, the District of Columbia, Florida, Maryland and Massachusetts have merged with 1199SEIU.

daodesc.p: 1199SEIU United Healthcare Workers, Jun 2010-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Actors' Equity Association ("AEA" or "Equity"), founded in 1913, is the labor union that represents more than 48,000 actors and stage managers in the United States. Equity seeks to advance, promote and foster the art of live theatre as an essential component of our society. Equity negotiates wages and working conditions and provides a wide range of benefits, including health and pension plans, for its members. Actors' Equity is a member of the AFL-CIO, and is affiliated with FIA, an international organization of performing arts unions.

daodesc.p: Actors' Equity Association, Sep 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Actors Fund, a nonprofit human services organization founded in 1882, serves professionals in film, theater, television, music, opera, and dance through programs that address their professional needs. The Fund serves more than 12,000 performing arts and entertainment professionals across the country every year, and reaches hundreds of thousand through the Fund’s online resources. The Fund operates as a safety net, to provide programs and services, including comprehensive social services, health services, supportive and affordable housing, employment and training services, and skilled nursing and assisted living care for performing arts and entertainment professionals in need.

daodesc.p: Actors' Fund of America., Sep 2007-present

did.unittitle: AFL-CIO New York City Central Labor Council

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The New York City Central Labor Council (NYCCLC) is a non-profit labor membership organization devoted to supporting, advancing and advocating for the working people of New York City. The NYCCLC brings together 300 local unions from every trade, occupation, public and private sector of the New York economy. The Council represents 1.3 million workers, including teachers, truck drivers, operating engineers, nurses, construction workers, electricians, firefighters, retail workers, janitors, train operators, bakers, and others. NYCCLC is affiliated with the AFL-CIO.

dao.ns2:title: AFL-CIO New York City Central Labor Council

daodesc.p: AFL-CIO New York City Central Labor Council, Sep 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: AFL-CIO Working Families Vote 2008 was an online political action arm of the AFL-CIO for the U.S. 2008 elections.

daodesc.p: AFL-CIO Working Families Vote 2008, Aug 2009-Mar 2010

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations (AFL-CIO) is a voluntary federation of 56 national and international labor unions. The AFL-CIO was created in 1955 by the merger of the AFL and the CIO. The AFL-CIO union movement represents 12.2 million members, including teachers, miners, firefighters, farm workers, bakers, engineers, pilots, public employees, doctors, nurses, painters, plumbers and other workers.

daodesc.p: AFL-CIO.org, Dec 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Air Line Pilots Association, International (ALPA) is the largest airline pilot union in the world and represents nearly 53,000 pilots at 36 U.S. and Canadian airlines. Founded in 1931, the Association is chartered by the AFL-CIO and the Canadian Labour Congress. Known internationally as US-ALPA, it is a member of the International Federation of Air Line Pilot Associations.

daodesc.p: Air Line Pilots Association (ALPA), Dec 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Albert Shanker Institute is a nonprofit foundation dedicated to advancing democratic ideals, improving the quality of public education, and conducting research in the labor movement and the sociology of work. The foundation sponsors research, holds roundtable discussions, and publishes various reports. The Institute was named for Albert Shanker (1928-1997), the late president of the American Federation of Teachers.

daodesc.p: Albert Shanker Institute, Jul 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Amalgamated Transit Union (ATU) is the largest labor organization representing transit workers in the United States and Canada. Founded in 1892, the ATU today is comprised of over 190,000 members in 264 local unions spread across 44 states and nine provinces. Composed of metropolitan, interstate, and school bus drivers; paratransit, light rail, subway, streetcar, and ferry boat operators; mechanics and other maintenance workers; clerks, baggage handlers, municipal employees, and others. The ATU works to promote transit issues and fights for the interests of its hard-working members. ATU is a member the AFL-CIO, and the Canadian Labor Congress (CLC).

daodesc.p: Amalgamated Transit Union (ATU), Dec 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Amalgamated Transit Union, Local 1181 is the largest local in the United States for the Amalgamated Transit Union. It represents drivers, escorts, school bus drivers, and mechanics in New York City, Westchester County and Long Island. The website contains information on their school bus strike in 2013, their pension and welfare fund, and a calendar.

daodesc.p: Amalgamated Transit Union, Local 1181, Jan 2013-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The American Federation of Government Employees (AFGE), founded in 1932, is an American labor union representing over 600,000 employees of the federal government, about 5,000 employees of the District of Columbia, and a few hundred private sector employees, mostly in and around federal facilities. Workers in many functions of government at every federal agency depend upon AFGE for legal representation, legislative advocacy, technical expertise and informational services. It is affiliated with the AFL-CIO.

daodesc.p: American Federation of Government Employees (AFGE), Dec 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians is a local union of professional musicians living or working in New York City, Nassau and Suffolk counties, New York. The union's mission is to fight for the interests and well being of the musicians employed in New York's music and entertainment industries through organizing and collective bargaining as well as through legislative and political action.

daodesc.p: American Federation of Musicians. Local 802, Sep 2007-present

did.unittitle: American Federation of Musicians of the United States and Canada (AFM)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The American Federation of Musicians of the United States and Canada (AFM) is a labor union of professional musicians in the United States and Canada, founded in 1896. The AFM represents the interests of professional musicians by negotiating fair agreements, protecting ownership of recorded music, securing benefits such as health care and pension, and lobbying legislators.

dao.ns2:title: American Federation of Musicians of the United States and Canada (AFM)

daodesc.p: American Federation of Musicians of the United States and Canada (AFM), Dec 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The American Federation of School Administrators (AFSA) is the national education union for school administrators, which provides labor relations and professional and occupational services to public school principals, vice principals, administrators and supervisors in diverse school districts across the U.S., Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands. Affiliated with the AFL-CIO, AFSA has been working for quality public school education for students of all backgrounds since 1976. AFSA’s mission is to promote the professional, occupational, and economic interests of its 20,000 members and work for the highest quality public school education for all pupils.

daodesc.p: American Federation of School Administrators (AFSA), Dec 2009-present

did.unittitle: American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees (AFSCME)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees (AFSCME), founded in 1932, is a public services employees union with more than 1.6 million active and retired members, consisting primarily of workers in the local and state government and in the health care industry. AFSCME organizes for social and economic rights of their members in the workplace and through political action and legislative advocacy.

dao.ns2:title: American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees (AFSCME)

daodesc.p: American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees (AFSCME), Dec 2009-present

did.unittitle: American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees (AFSCME) District Council 37 (New York, N.Y.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: District Council 37 (DC 37) is a local union of the American Federation of State, County, and Municipal Employees (AFSCME) which represents New York City public employees and employees in the healthcare industry. DC 37 was founded in 1944.

dao.ns2:title: American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees (AFSCME) District Council 37 (New York, N.Y.)

daodesc.p: American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees (AFSCME) District Council 37 (New York, N.Y.) , Sep 2007-present

did.unittitle: American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees (AFSCME) Local 1930 (New York, N.Y.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The New York Public Library Guild Local 1930, formed in 1968, represents almost 2,000 clericals, library technical assistants, information assistants, librarians, and other titles. Members of Local 1930 are employed by the New York Public Library, by the City of New York in its branch libraries, and the libraries of mayoral departments and agencies. The bargaining unit includes professional, non-professional and technical positions. As an activist union, they believe libraries are the backbone of democracy and unions are the vehicles to defend the economic rights of clerks, library technical assistants, information assistants, librarians, and others.

dao.ns2:title: American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees (AFSCME) Local 1930 (New York, N.Y.)

daodesc.p: American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees (AFSCME) Local 1930 (New York, N.Y.) , Sep 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The American Federation of Teachers (AFT), founded in 1916, represents the economic, social and professional interests of classroom teachers. It is an affiliated international union of the AFL-CIO. The AFT has more than 3,000 local affiliates nationwide, 43 state affiliates, and more than 1.5 million members. Five divisions within the organization represent the broad spectrum of AFT's membership: teachers; paraprofessionals and school-related personnel (PSRP); local, state and federal employees; higher education faculty and staff; and nurses and other healthcare professionals. In addition, the union includes more than 170,000 retiree members.

daodesc.p: American Federation of Teachers (AFT), Dec 2009-present

did.unittitle: American Federation of Television and Radio Artists

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The American Federation of Television and Radio Artists (AFTRA), founded in 1937, is a national labor union representing performers, journalists and other artists working in the entertainment and news media. AFTRA's scope of representation covers broadcast, public and cable television, radio, sound recordings, “non-broadcast” and industrial material, as well as Internet and digital programming. AFTRA advocates on legislative and public policy issues that directly affect members’ wages and working conditions. This includes lobbying and support for such issues as ownership consolidation in the broadcast industry, Equal Employment Opportunity laws and regulations, copyright and performance rights issues, “non-compete” restrictions, OSHA and local safety regulations, and more. AFTRA also represents artists and journalists in judicial proceedings, often as amicus, and before the U.S. Copyright Office. In 2012, AFTRA merged with the Screen Actors Guild (SAG) to form SAGAFTRA.

dao.ns2:title: American Federation of Television and Radio Artists.

daodesc.p: American Federation of Television and Radio Artists., Sep 2007-Jul 2012

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The American Guild of Musical Artists, AFL-CIO (AGMA), founded in 1936, is an American labor union that represents 8,000 current and retired opera singers, ballet and other dancers, opera directors, backstage production personnel at opera and dance companies, and figure skaters. AGMA is a branch of Associated Actors and Artistes of America.

daodesc.p: American Guild of Musical Artists, Nov 2008-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The American Guild of Variety Artists (AGVA) is an AFL-CIO-affiliated labor union founded in 1939 to represent performing artists and stage managers for live performances in the variety field. The variety area of performance includes singers and dancers in touring shows and in theatrical revues, theme park performers, skaters, circus performers, comedians & stand-up comics, cabaret & club artists, lecturers, poets, monologists, spokespersons, and variety performers working at private parties special events. AGVA is a branch of The Associated Actors and Artistes of America. AGVA negotiates contracts and provides relief for members. The website contains information on their relief funds, auditions, news, and other information.

daodesc.p: American Guild of Variety Artists, 4/23/2012-

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The American Labor Studies Center is a nonprofit organization whose mission is to collect, analyze, evaluate, create and disseminate labor history and labor studies curricula and related materials, aligned to the various state and national standards, to kindergarten through 12th grade teachers nationwide. They will include such areas as the history, organization, activities, and issues affecting the labor movement and the political, economic, and cultural aspects of workers and their unions. The ALSC sponsors workshops, courses, conferences and other events to acquaint teachers with the curriculum and related materials. The ALSC is located in Troy, New York in the Kate Mullany house. The website contains information for teachers, students, and unions.

daodesc.p: American Labor Studies Center (ALSC), Mar 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The American Postal Workers Union (APWU), formed in 1971, represents more than 220,000 United States Postal Service employees and retirees, and nearly 2,000 private-sector mail workers. It represents employees of the United States Postal Service who are clerks, maintenance employees, and motor vehicle service workers. APWU works for decent pay, benefits, and safe working conditions for workers they represent. The APWU is a Union Network International and AFL-CIO affiliate.

daodesc.p: American Postal Workers Union (APWU), Dec 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: American Rights at Work (ARAW), founded in 2003, is a U.S. nonpartisan, nonprofit organization that advocates for workers and their right to form unions without interference. ARAW is a labor policy and advocacy organization dedicated to educating the American public about the many barriers that workers face when they attempt to exercise their rights to organize and engage in collective bargaining. The organization conducts research into United States labor law and the National Labor Relations Board as they relate to unions, employer actions in union organizing, and collective bargaining campaign. ARAW’s resources include publications, Workers’ Rights Clearinghouse database, and Workers’ Rights Watch: Eye on the National Labor Relations Board.

daodesc.p: American Rights at Work, Sep 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The American Social History Project/Center for Media and Learning (ASHP/CML), founded in 1981, produces print, visual, and multimedia materials that explore the social and cultural history of the United States. They also lead development seminars. The website contains their digital projects, their “Who Built America?” series, documentaries, teaching services, and a their new media lab blog.

daodesc.p: American Social History Project , Jul 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Association for Union Democracy (AUD) is a pro-labor, non-profit organization dedicated solely to advancing the principles and practices of democratic trade unionism in the North American labor movement. AUD provides organizing, educational, and legal assistance to those working for greater membership control of their unions. AUD has operated several projects including, the Union Democracy Worker Education Project; the Women's Project; the Workers Rights Clinic; the AUD Steelworkers Fair Election Project; and the Longshore Workers Democracy Project.

daodesc.p: Association for Union Democracy, Sep 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Association of Flight Attendants-CWA (AFA-CWA), founded in 1945, is a union representing flight attendants in the United States. In 2011, AFA represents nearly 60,000 Flight Attendants at 23 airlines, making it the world's largest Flight Attendant union. The goal of flight attendants who become part of AFA-CWA is to negotiate better pay, benefits, working conditions, work rules at their airline, and to improve their safety on the job. The AFA is part of the Communication Workers of America (CWA), an affiliate with the AFL-CIO, and an affiliate of the 5 million member International Transport Workers' Federation.

daodesc.p: Association of Flight Attendants (AFA-CWA), Dec 2009-present

did.unittitle: Bakery, Confectionery, Tobacco Workers and Grain Millers International Union (BCTGM)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Bakery, Confectionery, Tobacco Workers and Grain Millers' International Union (BCTGM) is a labor union in the United States and Canada with a membership of 100,000. The union includes workers in bakeries, candy, cereal, sugar, grain mills, tobacco plants, food processing and manufacturing facilities and other related occupations related to these industries. The union traces its history to the founding of the Journeymen Bakers Union in 1886. The contemporary BCTGM was formed in January, 1999 from the merger of the Bakery, Confectionery and Tobacco Workers' International Union and the American Federation of Grain Millers. The BCTGM is affiliated with the AFL-CIO, the Canadian Labour Congress and the International Union of Food Workers (IUF).

dao.ns2:title: Bakery, Confectionery, Tobacco Workers and Grain Millers International Union (BCTGM)

daodesc.p: Bakery, Confectionery, Tobacco Workers and Grain Millers International Union (BCTGM) , Dec 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: B-Word Worldwide, affiliated with Bitch Media, is the nonprofit organization best known for publishing the magazine Bitch: Feminist Response to Pop Culture. Bitch Media’s mission is to provide and encourage an engaged, thoughtful feminist response to mainstream media and popular culture. The magazine was launched in 1996 by Lisa Jervis, Benjamin Shaykin, and Andi Zeisler.

daodesc.p: Bitch Magazine, Nov 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Black Workers for Justice (BWFJ) is a mass activist workers organization. It includes socialists, radical working class and general members, who link the immediate struggles in the workplaces and communities to a long term transitional radical program for Black empowerment/self-determination, social justice and social transformation. BWFJ was founded in 1981. Its labor and political perspectives grow out of an analysis of the development of the U.S. national and global economy, the U.S. imperialist state, and the ongoing role of the U.S. South as a fundamental pillar of U.S imperialism.

daodesc.p: Black Workers for Justice, May 2011-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 2007, Brandworkers is a New York City-based organization that works to protect and advance the rights of retail and food employees. By training workers in social change tools and facilitating member-led workplace justice campaigns, Brandworkers promotes employer compliance with the law and challenges corporate misconduct in the community. The website contains information on campaigns and programs, news, and blog posts.

daodesc.p: Brandworkers International, May 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Bread and Roses, part of the 1199SEIU, was founded in 1979, as a cultural resource for union members and students in New York City who would otherwise have little access to the arts. Bread and Roses established the only permanent union exhibition space in the nation, Gallery 1199, at the union’s New York City headquarters. Bread and Roses appears to be defunct as of 2009.

daodesc.p: Bread and Roses Cultural Project, Aug 2009

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Bread and Roses Heritage Committee is the organizing committee for the annual Bread and Roses Labor Day Festival in Lawrence, Massachusetts. The festival was created in honor of the Bread and Roses strike in 1912. The website contains a schedule of events, news, and Lawrence labor history.

daodesc.p: Bread and Roses Heritage Committee, Sep 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The International Union of Bricklayers and Allied Craftsmen, Local 1 was granted a charter by the National Union of Bricklayers of the U.S.A. on October 17, 1868 in Brooklyn, New York and is one of the oldest continuously-existing locals in New York City. The union represents bricklayers, plasterers, stonesetters, and pointers, cleaners and caulkers. The website contains their newsletter, events, and news listings.

daodesc.p: Bricklayers and Allied Craftworkers, Local 1, Dec 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Brotherhood of Railroad Signalmen, founded in 1901, represents nearly 9,500 signal employees on both the freight railroads and the passenger and commuter railroads across the United States and into Canada. The Brotherhood of Railroad Signalmen is affiliated with the AFL-CIO and the Transportation Trades Department.

dao.ns2:title: Brotherhood of Railroad Signalmen (BRS) - Grand Lodge

daodesc.p: Brotherhood of Railroad Signalmen (BRS) - Grand Lodge, 12/3/2009-

did.unittitle: Building and Construction Trades Department, AFL-CIO, (BCTD)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Building and Construction Trades Department, AFL-CIO, (BCTD) is the coordinating body of construction unions in the AFL-CIO. The department provides training and support to construction workers. It is made up of seven committees: Apprenticeship and Training; the Canadian Executive Board; General Presidents' Committee on Contract Maintenance; Labor-Management Committee; Legislative Task Force Committee; National Organizing Committee; and the Women in the Trades Committee. The website contains news, directories, legislative issues, and field services.

dao.ns2:title: Building and Construction Trades Department, AFL-CIO, (BCTD)

daodesc.p: Building and Construction Trades Department, AFL-CIO, (BCTD) , Oct 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Building Bridges: Your Community and Labor Report is a labor news web blog and a weekly one hour program covering local, national and international labor and community issues over radio WBAI-Pacifica 99.5 FM. Besides covering labor issues, the website focuses on human rights abuses, environmental concerns, US political domination abroad, and other social justice issues.

daodesc.p: Building Bridges Radio, Aug 2009-present

did.unittitle: Building Trades Employers' Association of the City of New York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Building Trades Employers Association (BTEA) is affiliated with 28 trade union contractor associations, representing the 1,700 construction managers, general contractors and specialty subcontractor firms in New York City, who employ 125,000 people. Members range in size from multi-billion dollar internationally recognized firms to small and mid-sized specialty trade contracting firms. The BTEA promotes safety, skill training, professional standards, and works to strengthen the economic vitality and social fabric of New York City.

dao.ns2:title: Building Trades Employers' Association of the City of New York

daodesc.p: Building Trades Employers' Association of the City of New York, Feb 2009-present

did.unittitle: California Nurses Association/National Nurses Organizing Committee (CNA/NNOC)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1903, the California Nurses Association, and its national arm, the National Nurses Organizing Committee is a labor organization of registered nurses and health care unions. CNA/NNOC has 86,000 members in 50 states, representing nurses at scores of hospitals, clinics, and home health agencies. Since 2000, over 19,000 RNs at 50 hospitals have elected to affiliate with CNA. CNA/NNOC is also a founding member of the 150,000-member National Nurses United.

dao.ns2:title: California Nurses Association/National Nurses Organizing Committee (CNA/NNOC)

daodesc.p: California Nurses Association/National Nurses Organizing Committee (CNA/NNOC), Dec 2009-Dec 2011

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Caucus of Rank and File Educators (CORE) is a coalition within the Chicago Teacher’s Union that took power in the union in 2010. They are against school privatization and led the 2012 Chicago teacher’s strike. The website contains news updates and a newsletter.

daodesc.p: Caucus of Rank-and-File Educators , Sep 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Center for Labor Renewal, launched in 2006, is a think tank dedicated to combining different threads of working class organizing and activism to promote the transformation and renewal of labor as a progressive social movement in this country and internationally.

daodesc.p: Center for Labor Renewal, May 2011-present

did.unittitle: Center for Study of Working Class Life

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Center for Study of Working Class Life, founded by the faculty and staff at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, in November, 1999, explores the meaning of class in the present day. The center studies social questions, including the gap between the rich and the poor, the attack on government programs through privatization, and other questions. The Center studies class mainly with tools of the social sciences, but also uses the arts as a tool of study.

dao.ns2:title: Center for Study of Working Class Life

daodesc.p: Center for Study of Working Class Life, May 2011-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Change to Win Strategic Organizing Center is a coalition of American labor unions formed in 2005. The coalition currently consists of four member unions: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters (IBT); Service Employees International Union (SEIU); United Farm Workers (UFW); and United Food and Commercial Workers (UFCW) and supports 5.5 million workers.

daodesc.p: Change to Win, Dec 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Chicago Teacher’s Union, chartered in 1937, represents 30,000 teachers and educational support personnel working in the Chicago Public Schools. The Chicago Teachers Union is an organization of educators dedicated to advancing and promoting quality public education, improving teaching and learning conditions, and protecting members' rights. They are affiliated with the Chicago Federation of Labor (CFL), the Illinois State Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations (ISFL-CIO), the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations (AFL-CIO), the Illinois Federation of Teachers (IFT), and the American Federation of Teachers (AFT). The website contains news, events, and information on their 2012 strike.

daodesc.p: Chicago Teachers Union, Sep 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Chinese Staff & Workers' Association (CSWA) was formed in New York City in 1979, to support over 1,300 workers from various trades and ages, injured and non-injured, documented and undocumented workers. It primarily assists workers in restaurants, the garment and construction industries, although it is active among workers in a variety of professions. The organization serves workers from all backgrounds, most of its members are Chinese and most of its efforts directed at employers in Chinatown.

daodesc.p: Chinese Staff Workers Association, Sep 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Civil Service Merit Council, founded in 1971, is a non-partisan coalition of individuals and organizations whose primary purpose was to increase the level of efficiency and integrity of government. The Merit Councils primary objective is to ensure that all appointments to the New York civil service shall be made through competitive examinations to properly classified positions from among persons duly qualified without regard to race, religion, age, sex, or political opinion or affiliation. The Council is dedicated to preserving and advancing the rights and tenure of all persons in the Merit System.

daodesc.p: Civil Service Merit Council, Feb 2009-Mar 2009

did.unittitle: Civil Service Technical Guild, Local 375, DC 37, AFSCME - AFL-CIO

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Civil Service Technical Guild (Local 375, DC 37), founded in 1929, represents 7,000 engineers, architects, scientists, chemists, planners, and other technical inspectors working for the City of New York. The guild’s goals include the prevention of the outsourcing city contracts, fighting for the adherence to civil service laws, enforcing contracts, and fighting privatization. The union is affiliated with the ASFCME and the AFL-CIO.

dao.ns2:title: Civil Service Technical Guild, Local 375, DC 37, AFSCME - AFL-CIO

daodesc.p: Civil Service Technical Guild, Local 375, DC 37, AFSCME - AFL-CIO , Sep 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Coalition of Black Trade Unionists (CBTU), founded in 1972, consists of members from seventy-seven international and national unions with fifty chapters across the country. It is the independent voice of black workers within the trade union movement, challenging organized labor to be more relevant to the needs and aspirations of black and poor workers.

daodesc.p: Coalition of Black Trade Unionists, Sep 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Coalition of Graduate Employee Unions was formed in 1992 to support the organization of new graduate employee unions; to strengthen established unions; and to provide a forum for graduate employee unionists to meet, share information and work together toward common goals. The coalition holds an annual conference featuring workshops on organizing, leadership development, negotiation strategies, and member mobilization. Each year, the conference is hosted by a different union; here are the locations and hosting unions (and international union affiliations) of the past ten conferences. This website is set up in a “wiki” format.

daodesc.p: Coalition of Graduate Employee Unions, Jul 2011-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Formed in 1974, Coalition of Labor Union Women (CLUW) is a nonpartisan organization whose primary mission is to unify all union women in a viable organization to determine our common problems and concerns and to develop action programs within the framework of our unions to deal effectively with our objectives. With members from 54 international and national unions across the U.S. and Canada, CLUW has a network of more than 40 chapters. CLUW is endorsed by the AFL-CIO and its international and national unions.

daodesc.p: Coalition of Labor Union Women (U.S.), Sep 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Committee for Free Trade Unionism (CFTU), was founded in ca. 2008 by Thomas R. Donahue, President Emeritus of the AFL-CIO, and appears to be largely composed of individuals involved with the group Social Democrats USA. CFTU aims to promote trade union freedom by working with a worldwide network of trade union experts and other groups committed to the advancement of free trade unionism, galvanize the efforts of international labor, and providing defenses against trade union persecution and oppression anywhere in the world.

daodesc.p: Committee for Free Trade Unionism, Sep 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Communications Workers of America (CWA), founded in 1947, is America's largest communications and media union, represents over 700,000 men and women in both private and public sectors, including over half a million workers who are employed in telecommunications, broadcasting, cable TV, journalism, publishing, electronics and general manufacturing, as well as airline customer service, government service, health care, education and other fields. The union includes some 1,200 chartered local unions across the United States, Canada and Puerto Rico. Members live in approximately 10,000 communities, making CWA one of the most geographically diverse unions. CWA is headquartered in Washington, DC, and affiliated with the AFL-CIO, the Canadian Labour Congress, and Union Network International

daodesc.p: Communications Workers of America, Sep 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: District 1 of the Communications Workers of America (CWA) includes 327 CWA local unions in New York, New Jersey, New England, and eastern Canada. Members are employed in many different sectors of the economy including, telecommunications; health care; higher education; manufacturing; broadcast and cable television; commercial printing and newspapers; state, local, and country government.

daodesc.p: Communications Workers of America, District 1, Sep 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: District 2-13 is responsible for servicing all CWA locals in Pennsylvania, Maryland, Delaware, Virginia, West Virginia, and the District of Columbia. Members are employed in many different sectors of the economy including, telecommunications; health care; higher education; manufacturing; broadcast and cable television; commercial printing and newspapers; state, local, and country government.

daodesc.p: Communications Workers of America, District 2-13, Mar 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Communications Workers of America Local 1032 represents about 6,000 workers in a variety of professions and fields in several New Jersey State Departments, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, several New Jersey towns and counties as well as several private sector work sites.

daodesc.p: Communications Workers of America. Local 1032, Feb 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: CWA Local 1060 represents workers at Lucent (formerly Bell Labs, in Murray Hill, NJ). The website contains information on benefits, minutes, financials, and news.

daodesc.p: Communication Workers of America Local 1060, Nov 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: mmunication Workers of America, Local 1103 is based in New York, New York.

daodesc.p: Communications Workers of America, Local 1101, Feb 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Communication Workers of America, Local 1103 is based in Port Chester, New York.

daodesc.p: Communications Workers of America, Local 1103, Mar 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Communications Workers of America Local 1109 represents over 2,000 telecommunications technicians and customer service representatives in Brooklyn, New York. The website contains information on benefits, political action campaigns, their publication, the Wire, and news.

daodesc.p: Communication Workers of America, Local 1109, Nov 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Communication Workers of America, Local 1150 is based in New York, NY, and represents landline technicians in the New York and New Jersey metropolitan area.

daodesc.p: Communications Workers of America, Local 1150, Feb 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Communications Workers of America, Local 1153 was chartered in 1975, after more than 500 members of the Manhattan-based Local 1150 petitioned for a new local to represent American Telephone & Telegraph's Long Lines (long distance) employees working in the White Plains and Mount Kisco area. 1153 consists of three sections: Plant (construction and maintenance), Traffic (operators) and Administrative (clerical). Local 1153 advocates for many issues, including job losses, job pressures, seniority rights, the creation of new job titles, health and safety, and discrimination based on sex and race.

daodesc.p: Communications Workers of America, Local 1153, Feb 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Local 1180 is an affiliate of the Communications Workers of America (CWA), representing over 8,000 workers in the New York City area. Members work in the public sector, but the union also represents workers at the Board of Education, the Housing Authority, the Transit Authority, the School Construction Authority, the state's Unified Court System; at private companies such as the Jacob Javits Convention Center; and at not-for-profit organizations including Planned Parenthood of New York City, the ASPCA, Human Rights First, and Human Rights Watch.

daodesc.p: Communications Workers of America, Local 1180, Sep 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Cyberunions, created by Walter Pantland, works to get trade unions to use technology to organize and building an open source labor movement. The site contains both theoretical pieces on and more practical resources for activists. The website also produces a podcast on trade unions, technology, and economics.

daodesc.p: Cyberunions, Nov 2011-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: David Bacon is photojournalist, labor organizer, and immigrant-rights activist, and author. The website contains photographs and articles by Bacon.

daodesc.p: David Bacon Photographs and Stories, Sep 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: District Council 1707 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees (AFSCME) is the only council within AFSCME that is chartered exclusively to represent private, nonprofit employees. It currently represents about 25,000 workers throughout the New York City area (and New York State), including those within private sector fundraising and advocacy agencies, case work and group work agencies, teaching and related organizations, child care centers, home care services, and Head Start programs. The website contains information on the political action committee, class and workshops, benefits, and news.

daodesc.p: District Council 1707, Nov 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Initially founded in 2000 by the Women Workers Project of Committee of Against Anti-Asian Violence, the Domestic Workers United (DWU) is an organization of Caribbean, Latina and African nannies, housekeepers, and caregivers for the elderly in New York, organizing for fair labor standards and to help build a movement to end exploitation and oppression. DWU organizes workers from the Caribbean, Africa and Latin America, and coordinates with the other domestic workers organizations through the NY Domestic Workers Justice Coalition to build the power of the entire workforce.

daodesc.p: Domestic Workers United, May 2011-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Embedded With Organized Labor is the labor blog by Steve Early. Steve Early is a labor journalist and lawyer who has written for numerous publications. He is the author of Embedded With Organized Labor: Journalistic Reflections on the Class War at Home and The Civil Wars in U.S. Labor. Early was a Boston-based international representative or organizer for the Communications Workers of America for 27 years, and is a member of the editorial advisory committees of three independent labor publications: Labor Notes, New Labor Forum and Working USA.

daodesc.p: Embedded With Organized Labor, Dec 2011-Dec 2012

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Employee Free Choice Act was a legislative bill that was introduced into both chambers of the U.S. Congress on March 10, 2009. The bill's purpose was to, “amend the National Labor Relations Act to establish an efficient system to enable employees to form, join, or assist labor organizations [unions], to provide for mandatory injunctions for unfair labor practices during organizing efforts, and for other purposes.” This website was a petition website in support of the act. The central part of the legislation would have provided for automatic certification of unions if a majority of potential members had signed unionization cards

daodesc.p: Employee Free Choice Act Now!, Dec 2008-Dec 2010

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Excluded Worker Congress consists of networks of organizations that represent a base of workers that are either by law or by practice excluded from the right to organize. The nine sectors of the Excluded Workers Congress include domestic workers, farm workers, taxi drivers, restaurant workers, day laborers, guest workers, workers from Southern right- to-work states, workfare workers and formerly incarcerated workers. They are a project of the Inter-Alliance Dialogue, an alliance of Grassroots Global Justice Alliance, Jobs with Justice, National Day Labor Organizing Network, National Domestic Worker Alliance, Pushback Network, and Right to the City Alliance and affiliated with the AFL-CIO and other unions.

daodesc.p: Excluded Workers Congress, Oct 2011-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Farm Labor Organizing Committee, AFL-CIO, (FLOC), founded in 1967, is a labor union representing migrant farm workers in the Midwestern United States and North Carolina.

daodesc.p: Farm Labor Organizing Committee (FLOC), Dec 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Fruit of Labor Singing Ensemble is a labor affiliated singing group that grew out of the struggle of organizing African American workers in the “Black Belt” region of North Carolina and the South. Their music captures the working class’ history of community and workplace struggles. The website features their music and event listings.

daodesc.p: Fruit of Labor Singing Ensemble, July 2012-present

did.unittitle: Glass, Molders, Pottery, Plastics and Allied Workers International Union (GMP)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Glass, Molders, Pottery, Plastics & Allied Workers (GMP) International Union, with its origins dating back to 1842 represents thousands of workers in the glass, molders, plastics, pottery, cast metals, fiberglass, defense, fine china, glass and plastic containers, insulation and sanitary-ware industries as well as workers in government, healthcare and a variety of other industries. The GMP International Union currently belongs to the AFL-CIO, CLC and is active in the Union Label and Service Trades Department as well as the Maritime Trades Department.

dao.ns2:title: Glass, Molders, Pottery, Plastics and Allied Workers International Union (GMP)

daodesc.p: Glass, Molders, Pottery, Plastics and Allied Workers International Union (GMP), Dec 2009-present

did.unittitle: Graduate Student Organizing Committee (GSOC), UAW Local 2110

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: GSOC/UAW Local 2110 is the union of teaching, research and graduate assistants at New York University. As the chosen representative of the majority of NYU graduate employees, the Graduate Student Organizing Committee (GSOC) is committed to restoring collective bargaining rights for our membership and forcing NYU to once again recognize our union, as it did when GSOC and NYU signed a contract governing graduate employment in 2002. Collective bargaining gives employees a say in their working conditions by empowering chosen representatives of those workers to negotiate with employers over issues like pay, workload protections, workplace safety and benefits.

dao.ns2:title: Graduate Student Organizing Committee (GSOC), UAW Local 2110

daodesc.p: Graduate Student Organizing Committee (GSOC), UAW Local 2110, Jul 2011-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Guerrilla News Network is an independent news organization with headquarters in New York City and production facilities in Berkeley, California. Their mission is to expose people to important global issues through cross-platform guerrilla programming.

daodesc.p: Guerrilla News Network, Feb 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Industrial Workers of the World, founded in 1905, is a member-run union for all workers, dedicated to organizing on the job, in industries and communities. IWW members are organizing to win better conditions and build a world with economic democracy. IWW works to change the atmosphere in workplaces run for the benefit of workers and communities. The IWW contends that all workers should be united as a class and that the wage system should be abolished. They may be best known for the Wobbly Shop model of workplace democracy, in which workers elect recallable delegates, and other norms of grassroots democracy (self-management) are implemented.

daodesc.p: Industrial Workers of the World, Feb 2007-present

did.unittitle: International Alliance of Theatrical and Stage Employees, Local 52

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: International Alliance of Theatrical and Stage Employees, Local 52 was founded in the early 1920s, and was officially chartered by the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees (IATSE) in 1924. The local’s jurisdiction includes, New York, New Jersey, Delaware, Pennsylvania (with the exception of Pittsburgh), and Connecticut. The labor union represents technicians, artisans and craftspeople in the entertainment industry, including live theatre, motion picture and television production, and trade shows.

dao.ns2:title: International Alliance of Theatrical and Stage Employees, Local 52

daodesc.p: International Alliance of Theatrical and Stage Employees, Local 52, Feb 2009-present

did.unittitle: International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, Moving Picture Technicians, Artists and Allied Crafts of the United States, Its Territories and Canada (IATSE)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, Moving Picture Technicians, Artists and Allied Crafts of the United States, Its Territories and Canada was originally chartered by the American Federation of Labor as the National Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees in 1893. With 110,000 members, the labor union represents technicians, artisans and craftspeople in the entertainment industry, including live theatre, motion picture and television production, and trade shows.

dao.ns2:title: International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, Moving Picture Technicians, Artists and Allied Crafts of the United States, Its Territories and Canada (IATSE)

daodesc.p: International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, Moving Picture Technicians, Artists and Allied Crafts of the United States, Its Territories and Canada (IATSE), Dec 2009-present

did.unittitle: International Association of Bridge, Structural, Ornamental and Reinforcing Iron Workers (Ironworkers)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The International Association of Bridge, Structural, Ornamental and Reinforcing Iron Workers Union, AFL-CIO, founded in 1896, represents primarily construction workers, as well as shipbuilding and metal fabrication employees. The current membership stands at approximately 140,000, with 15,000 apprentices.

dao.ns2:title: International Association of Bridge, Structural, Ornamental and Reinforcing Iron Workers (Ironworkers)

daodesc.p: International Association of Bridge, Structural, Ornamental and Reinforcing Iron Workers (Ironworkers) , Dec 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The International Association of Fire Fighters (IAFF), found in 1918 and headquartered in Washington, DC, represents more than 295,000 full-time professional fire fighters and paramedics who protect 85 percent of the nation’s population. More than 3,100 affiliates and their members protect communities in every state in the United States and in Canada. The IAFF is one of the most active lobbying organizations in Washington; its Political Action Committee, FIREPAC, is among the top 25 federal PACs among the more than 4,000 in the country.

daodesc.p: International Association of Fire Fighters(IAFF), Dec 2009-present

did.unittitle: International Association of Heat and Frost Insulators and Allied Workers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: International Association of Heat and Frost Insulators and Allied Workers, was formerly known as the International Association of Heat and Frost Insulators and Asbestos Workers. One of the major jobs of the members of the union has long been the safe removal of hazardous asbestos-containing materials, which were previously used in many construction products, such as insulation, adhesives, caulks, and flooring tiles. The object of the International Association of Heat and Frost Insulators and Allied Workers is to assist its membership in securing employment, to defend their rights and advance their interests as working men and women, and by education and cooperation, raise them to that position in society to which they are justly entitled.

dao.ns2:title: International Association of Heat and Frost Insulators and Allied Workers

daodesc.p: International Association of Heat and Frost Insulators and Allied Workers, Dec 2009-present

did.unittitle: International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers (IAM)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, founded in 1888, is an AFL-CIO/CLC trade union representing approx. 646,933 workers as of 2006 in more than 200 industries, The union represents machinists, aerospace, and transportation workers.

dao.ns2:title: International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers

daodesc.p: International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers , Dec 2009-present

did.unittitle: International Brotherhood of Boilermakers, Iron Ship Builders, Blacksmiths, Forgers and Helpers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The International Brotherhood of Boilermakers, Iron Ship Builders, Blacksmiths, Forgers and Helpers, organized in 1880, represents 100,000 workers in heavy industry, shipbuilding, manufacturing, railroads, cement, mining, and related industries. The Boilermakers union has a four-year apprenticeship training program. Boilermakers primarily work in nuclear and fossil power plants. However they also work in shipyards, refineries and chemical plants. The work involves welding, rigging and fabricating. All work done is governed by OSHA (Occupational Safety and Health Administration) or MSHA (Mine Safety and Health Administration).

dao.ns2:title: International Brotherhood of Boilermakers, Iron Ship Builders, Blacksmiths, Forgers and Helpers

daodesc.p: International Brotherhood of Boilermakers, Iron Ship Builders, Blacksmiths, Forgers and Helpers, Dec 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers (IBEW) is a labor union which represents workers in the electrical industry in the United States, Canada, Panama and several Caribbean island nations; particularly electricians, or Inside Wiremen, in the construction industry and linemen and other employees of public utilities. The union also represents some workers in the computer, telecommunications, broadcasting, and other fields related to electrical work. It was founded in 1891 shortly after homes and businesses in the United States began receiving electricity. The IBEW is affiliated with the AFL-CIO.

daodesc.p: International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers (IBEW) , Dec 2009-present

did.unittitle: International Brotherhood of Painters and Allied Trades. Painters District Council 9 of New York City

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The District Council 9 New York is local branch of the International Union of Painters and Allied Trades, chartered in 1900. District Council 9 is an organization of painters, decorators, wall covers, drywall finishers, sign painters, metal polishers, bridge & structural steel painters, civil service painters, lead abatement workers, glaziers & architectural metal glassworkers, paint makers, paint makers and allied trades.

dao.ns2:title: International Brotherhood of Painters and Allied Trades. Painters District Council 9 of New York City

daodesc.p: International Brotherhood of Painters and Allied Trades. Painters District Council 9 of New York City, Sep 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters (IBT) is a labor union in the United States and Canada. Formed in 1903 by the merger of several local and regional locals of teamsters, the union now represents a diverse membership of blue-collar and professional workers, notably truckers, in both the public and private sectors. The union had approximately 1.4 million members in 2008. Formerly known as the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Warehousemen and Helpers of America, the IBT is a member of the Change to Win Federation and Canadian Labour Congress.

daodesc.p: International Brotherhood of Teamsters (IBT), Dec 2009-present

did.unittitle: International Federation of Professional and Technical Engineers (IFPTE)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1918, the International Federation of Professional and Technical Engineers, AFL-CIO & CLC, represents more than 80,000 men and women in professional, technical, administrative and associated occupations, representing employees in a wide variety of occupations in the federal, public, and private sectors.

dao.ns2:title: International Federation of Professional and Technical Engineers (IFPTE)

daodesc.p: International Federation of Professional and Technical Engineers (IFPTE), Dec 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The International Labor Communications Association (ILCA), founded in 1955, is the professional organization of labor communicators in North America. ILCA membership is open to national, regional, and local union publications and to media productions affiliated with the AFL-CIO and the CLC. The ILCA works to strengthen and expand labor print publications, websites, and radio, television, and film productions by providing resources, expertise, and networking opportunities for labor communicators.

daodesc.p: International Labor Communications Association, Feb 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The International Longshore and Warehouse Union (ILWU) is a labor union which primarily represents dock workers on the West Coast of the United States, Hawaii and Alaska, and in British Columbia, Canada. It also represents hotel workers in Hawaii, cannery workers in Alaska, warehouse workers throughout the West and bookstore workers in Portland, Oregon. The union was established in 1937 after the 1934 West Coast Waterfront Strike, a 3-month-long strike that culminated in a 4-day general strike in San Francisco, California, and the Bay Area. The ILWU is affiliated with the Inland Boatmen's Union of the Pacific.

daodesc.p: International Longshore and Warehouse Union (ILWU) , Dec 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Organized in 1892, the International Longshoremen's Association (ILA), AFL-CIO represents maritime workers in North America, representing upwards of 65,000 longshoremen on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, Great Lakes, major U.S. rivers, Puerto Rico and Eastern Canada. The union is also affiliated with the International Transport Workers' Federation, the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots; the United Marine Division Tugboat Workers, and the officers of the New York State Supreme Court Officers are also affiliated with the ILA.

daodesc.p: International Longshoremen's Association (ILA), Dec 2009-present

did.unittitle: International Union of Bricklayers and Allied Craftworkers (BAC)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Bricklayers and Allied Craftsworkers (BAC) Local 7, established in 1994, was formed from seven BAC locals. Local 7, and is part of the International Union of Bricklayers and Allied Craftworkers which, represents craftworkers in the trowel trades. BAC Local 7 represents workers in the New York and New Jersey area.

dao.ns2:title: International Union of Bricklayers and Allied Craftworkers (BAC)

daodesc.p: International Union of Bricklayers and Allied Craftworkers (BAC), Dec 2009-present

did.unittitle: International Union of Bricklayers and Allied Craftworkers. Local 7 (New York and New Jersey)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1865, the International Union of Bricklayers and Allied Craftworkers represents craftworkers in the trowel trades across the United States and Canada including bricklayers, stone and marble masons, cement masons, plasterers, tilesetters, terrazzo and mosaic workers, and pointers/cleaners/caulkers.

dao.ns2:title: International Union of Bricklayers and Allied Craftworkers. Local 7 (New York and New Jersey)

daodesc.p: International Union of Bricklayers and Allied Craftworkers. Local 7 (New York and New Jersey), May 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The International Union of Elevator Constructors (IUEC) is a trade union in the United States and Canada of individuals who construct, modernize, repair, and service elevators, escalators, moving walkways, and other conveyances. The IUEC claims a membership of over 25,000 and was founded in 1901.

daodesc.p: International Union of Elevator Constructors (IUEC), Dec 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The International Union of Operating Engineers (IUOE) represents primarily construction workers who work as heavy equipment operators, mechanics, surveyors, and stationary engineers (also called operating engineers or power engineers) who maintain heating and other systems in buildings and industrial complexes. Founded in 1896, it currently represents roughly 400,000 workers in approximately 170 local unions and operates nearly 100 apprenticeship programs. IUOE also represents nurses and other health industry workers, a significant number of public employees engaged in a wide variety of occupations, as well as a number of job classifications in the petrochemical industry.

daodesc.p: International Union of Operating Engineers (IUOE), Dec 2009-present

did.unittitle: International Union of Painters and Allied Trades

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1887, the International Union of Painters and Allied Trades, represents men and women in North America who work in the Finishing Trades of commercial and industrial painting, drywall finishing, glazing, floor covering, sign and trade show/convention display. The union is made up of 160,000 members. The website contains information on training sessions, publications, and their children’s foundation.

dao.ns2:title: International Union of Painters and Allied Trades

daodesc.p: International Union of Painters and Allied Trades, Apr 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The International Union of Police Associations (IUPA), founded in 1954, is an AFL-CIO chartered union for law enforcement, corrections, and law enforcement support personnel. IUPA works to support legislation that protects and affects public safety officers. Some legislative initiatives include the National Police Officers Bill of Rights, Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) for public employees, educational survivor benefits and armor vest grants.

daodesc.p: International Union of Police Associations (IUPA), Dec 2009-present

did.unittitle: International Union, United Automobile, Aerospace and Agricultural Implement Workers of America (UAW)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The International Union, United Automobile, Aerospace and Agricultural Implement Workers of America also known as the United Auto Workers (UAW), founded in 1935, is a trade union that represents workplaces ranging from multinational corporations, small manufacturers and state and local governments to colleges and universities, hospitals and private non-profit organizations. UAW members work in industries as diverse as automobile and parts manufacturing, health care, casino gaming and higher education. The UAW has more than 750 local unions, with 390,000 active members and more than 600,000 retired members in the United States, Canada and Puerto Rico.

dao.ns2:title: International Union, United Automobile, Aerospace and Agricultural Implement Workers of America (UAW)

daodesc.p: International Union, United Automobile, Aerospace and Agricultural Implement Workers of America (UAW), Sep 2007-present

dao.ns2:title: International Union, United Automobile, Aerospace and Agricultural Implement Workers of America (UAW)

daodesc.p: International Union, United Automobile, Aerospace and Agricultural Implement Workers of America (UAW), Sep 2007-present

did.unittitle: International Union, United Automobile, Aerospace and Agricultural Implement Workers of America (UAW) Local 2110

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Technical, Office and Professional (TOP) Union, Local 2110, is an amalgamated union with contracts covering workers in universities, publishing, museums, law firms and other offices, including teachers, secretaries, administrators, editors, computer operators, librarians, museum curators, typesetters and graphic artists. They promote benefits such as childcare, flex-time, job classification, domestic partner benefits and family leave. They are affiliated with the UAW and AFL-CIO.

dao.ns2:title: International Union, United Automobile, Aerospace and Agricultural Implement Workers of America (UAW) Local 2110

daodesc.p: International Union, United Automobile, Aerospace and Agricultural Implement Workers of America (UAW) Local 2110, Mar 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Jewish Labor Committee, an independent secular organization, is the voice of the Jewish community in the labor movement and the voice of the labor movement in the Jewish community. The JLC was formed in 1934 by Yiddish-speaking immigrant trade union leaders and leaders of such groups as the Workmen's Circle/Arbeter Ring, the Jewish Labor Bund, and the United Hebrew Trades, in response to the rise of Nazism in Germany. The JLC enables the Jewish community and the trade union movement to work together on important issues of shared interest and concern, in pursuit of economic and social justice.

daodesc.p: Jewish Labor Committee, Mar 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Jobs with Justice, founded in 1987, is a national network of local coalitions that bring together labor unions, faith groups, community organizations, and student activists who fight for working people through long-term multi-issue coalition building, grassroots base-building, organizing, and strategic militant action. Jobs with Justice coalitions also worked on 127 community campaigns on issues like jobs and the economy, health care, immigrants' rights, global justice, accountable development, and sweat-free ordinances.

daodesc.p: Jobs With Justice, Feb 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This website contains the Kid from Hoboken series, the autobiography of Bill Bailey (1911–1995). Bill Bailey was a veteran of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade and labor activist.

daodesc.p: The Kid from Hoboken, Jul 2012

did.unittitle: Labor and Working Class History Association

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Labor and Working Class History Association (LAWCHA) is an organization of historians, labor educations, and working class activists who seek to promote public and scholarly awareness of labor and working class history through research, writing, and organizing. The organization also promotes labor and working class history put into history and social studies curricula in public schools, colleges, and universities. LAWCHA gives grants and prizes to graduate students. The LAWCHA also publishes the journal, Labor: Studies in Working-Class History of the Americas.

daodesc.p: Labor and Working-Class History Association, Oct 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Labor Arts was created in 2000 by Donald Rubin, Evelyn Jones Rich, Moe Foner (1915-2002), Henry Foner, Esther Cohen, Rachel Bernstein and Debra E. Bernhardt (1953-2001), initially sponsored by the Shelley and Donald Rubin Foundation, Bread and Roses, the cultural arm of the hospital workers' local 1199, Service Employees International Union (SEIU), and the Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives/Tamiment Library at New York University. Labor Arts acts as a virtual museum to gather, identify, and display examples of the cultural and artistic history of working people and trade unions.

daodesc.p: Labor Arts, Sep 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Labor Community Strategy Center, founded in 1989, is a think tank for regional, national, and international movement building, based in Los Angeles. The Strategy Center works on campaigns, projects, and publications rooted in working class urban communities of color with a particular focus on civil rights, environmental justice, public health, global warming, and the criminal legal system. They work to build leadership, and organization among those who face discrimination and societal attack. The Strategy Center develops campaigns and demands to attempt to build a world without war, racism, and imperialism through radical and structural change. The organization runs Frontlines Press, which produces books, pamphlets, radio shows, and films.

daodesc.p: Labor Community Strategy Center, May 2011-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Labor Express, created in 1993 by former SEIU organizer Wayne Heimbach, as part of the programming on WLUW, 88.7 FM. Labor Express is a Chicago-based radio program on labor news and current events. They cover local, national, and international news on living wage jobs, healthcare, education, immigrant rights, the environment, and issues of race and gender. The program is a production of the Committee for Labor Access.

daodesc.p: Labor Express, Nov 2011-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Labor Heritage Foundation (LHF) which was founded in 1983, works to preserve and promote knowledge of the cultural heritage of the American worker through the arts, including music, poetry, written works, theatre, and artistic works; and conducts historical research through written and oral histories. LHF’s mission is to strengthen the labor movement through arts and music. LHF affiliates include, the LHF Catalogue (print and online catalogue of art related to the labor movement), the Great Labor Arts Exchange conference, awards, and other conferences.

daodesc.p: Labor Heritage Foundation, Sep 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This site is a comprehensive bibliography of information, documents and links relating to U.S. labor history. It was developed by labor historian Rosemary Feurer for the Labor and Working Class History Association.

daodesc.p: Labor History Links Home Page, Oct 2011-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Labor Network for Sustainability (LNS) is a labor network dedicated to engaging trade unions, workers and allies to support economic, social, and environmental sustainability. The organization addresses issues such as climate protection, food security, economic justice, corporate accountability, water availability to renewable energy. The website contains information on issues, joining the network, blog posts, and the Green Workers Alliance.

daodesc.p: Labor Network for Sustainability, May 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Labor Notes, founded in 1979, is a non-profit organization and network for rank-and-file union members and grassroots labor activists. Though officially titled the Labor Education and Research Project, the project is best known by the title of its monthly magazine. The magazine, both print and online, reports on news and analysis about labor activity or problems facing the labor movement. In its pages it advocates for a revitalization of the labor movement through Social Movement Unionism and union democracy. [Labor Notes is widely believed to have been an initiative of the International Socialist Organization, a Trotskyist group with organizations in the United States and other countries.]
