daodesc.p: Labor Notes, Feb 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Labor Press is an organization that includes a news, public relations, and promotional service for the New York labor community. Labor Press also maintains a website on current labor, building trades, retail, education, health and safety, and environmental issues. Labor Press produces newsletters, publications, websites, and targeted campaign materials for unions.

daodesc.p: Labor Press, Oct 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Labor Beat, aka the Chicago-based Committee for Labor Access (CLA), founded in 1987, advocates for labor’s rank-and-file to have its own media and produce their own labor television and radio shows and news clips. CLA develops and distributes progressive television, radio, videos, and Internet communications on unions and workers issues. They are affiliated with Local 1220 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.

daodesc.p: Labor Beat, Feb 2007-present

did.unittitle: Laborers' International Union of North America

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Laborers’ International Union of North America (LIUNA), founded in 1903, is a union of semi-skilled construction workers. The union consists of a half million workers. The union supports workers through collective bargaining agreements, which earn family-supporting pay, good benefits and the opportunity for advancement. The website contains information on the structure of the union, press releases, and other information about the union.

dao.ns2:title: Laborers' International Union of North America

daodesc.p: Laborers' International Union of North America, Apr 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: LaborFest, established in 1994, is a labor, cultural, and film festival held annually in July in San Francisco. The festival was established in honor of the “Bloody Thursday” event and longshoremen and maritime workers strike in 1934. The website features schedules, videos, images, and other information on the current and previous years’ events. The website contains a schedule of events, which include film screenings, concerts, talks, and walking tours. The website also contains links and other multimedia.

daodesc.p: LaborFest, Aug 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: LaborNet, founded in 1991, is an organization created to build a democratic communication network for the labor movement and rebuild the labor movement with new technology. LaborNets are also established in the United Kingdom, Austria, Germany, Korea, Turkey, and Japan. LaborNet also works to defend the Internet from censorship and the privatization of information that would limit and destroy the rights to communicate and build world unionism. The website aggregates news related to the labor movement.

daodesc.p: LaborNet (U.S.), Feb 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: LaborTech brings together labor video, computer, and media activists to build and develop labor communications in technology and media. The website holds conferences (the first held in 1990) and campaigns to strengthen the labor movement.

daodesc.p: LaborTech, Nov 2010-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Manumit School was an “experimental boarding school in Pawling NY. Founded on purchased farm land in 1924 by William and Helen Fincke, it was formally call the Manumit School for Workers’ Children. An early promotional flyer for the school asked parents if they’d like their children to grow up “to become men and women who can think for themselves, stand on their own two feet and fight injustice and oppression. “ It’s teachings were meant to provide a “progressive “ “workers education” slant during a time of increasing socialist optimism in America. In 1944 the school moved to Bensalem Township, Bucks County, Pennsylvania. The school closed in 1957. This website is an informational website.

daodesc.p: Manumit School (1924-1957), Sep 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Marine Engineers' Beneficial Association (MEBA) is the oldest maritime trade union in the United States still currently in existence, established in 1875. MEBA primarily represents licensed mariners, especially deck and engine officers working in the United States Merchant Marine aboard U.S.-flagged vessels. It is a member union of the AFL–CIO. MEBA officers work in both the oceans and the Great Lakes in many settings, including on container ships, tankers (including LNG carriers), cruise ships, drillships, tugboats, ferries, and fireboats, as well as in various capacities in the shore side ship transport and marine industries and on government-contracted ships of the United States Maritime Administration's Ready Reserve Force and United States Navy's Military Sealift Command.

daodesc.p: Marine Engineers' Beneficial Association (MEBA) , Dec 2009-present

did.unittitle: Metro New York Labor Communications Council

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Metro New York Labor Communications Council (Metro), established in 1974, is a council which consists of editors, writers, artists, photographers, graphic designers, web designers, radio program producers, labor public relations specialists, and video producers from public and private sector trade unions, related organizations, and others in the labor movement. Metro provides a forum to exchange ideas and information and to discuss the problems and questions that confront labor communicators in their work. The Council offers skills orientated workshops, seminars, journalism awards, and an annual convention to discuss relevant issues regarding the labor movement. Metro is affiliated with the International Labor Communications Association of the AFL-CIO, and cooperates with the New York City Central Labor Council.

dao.ns2:title: Metro New York Labor Communications Council

daodesc.p: Metro New York Labor Communications Council, May 2010-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Million Worker March was a rally on October 17, 2004 on in Washington DC. The rally was against perceived attacks on the working class families. Approximately 10000 people marched on Washington.

daodesc.p: Million Worker March Movement, Jul 2011-Feb 2013

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: National Air Traffic Controllers Association (NATCA) represents over 20,000 controllers, engineers and other safety-related professionals, including engineers, traffic management coordinators and staff specialists, with membership from every state, territory and possession of the United States. Certified in 1987, NATCA is affiliated with the AFL-CIO.

daodesc.p: National Air Traffic Controllers Association (NATCA), Dec 2009-present

did.unittitle: National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians, Communication Workers of America

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians-Communications Workers of America (NABET-CWA), founded in 1934, is a Union of workers who are employed in the broadcasting, distributing, telecasting, recording, cable, video, sound recording and related industries in North America. NABET-CWA has contracts with ABC, NBC, FOX and other networks, as well as local TV stations across the country and members include engineers, photographers, editors, directors, technicians, graphic artists, traffic coordinators, clerical workers, truck operators, writers, reporters, anchors, producers and others in the television and cable industry.

dao.ns2:title: National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians, Communication Workers of America

daodesc.p: National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians, Communication Workers of America, Mar 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The National Association of Letter Carriers (NALC) is an American labor union, representing non-rural letter carriers employed by the United States Postal Service. It was founded in 1889.

daodesc.p: National Association of Letter Carriers (NALC) , Dec 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 2007, the National Domestic Workers Alliance organizes domestic workers in the United States to improve their living and working conditions, win respect and justice from employers and government for exploited domestic workers; challenge racism and sexism; end the exclusion of domestic workers from recognition and protection; and build a movement of migrant workers to fight the labor displacement and exploitation created by globalization.

daodesc.p: National Domestic Workers Alliance, Oct 2011-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The National Education Association (NEA), founded in 1857, is the largest professional organization and largest labor union in the United States, representing public school teachers and other support personnel, faculty and staffers at colleges and universities, retired educators, and college students preparing to become teachers. The NEA has 3.2 million members and is headquartered in Washington, D.C. It has affiliate organizations in every state and in more than 14,000 communities across the United States.

daodesc.p: National Education Association, Dec 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: National Guestworker Alliance, founded in 2005 as the Alliance of Guestworkers, is a membership organization of guestworkers and organizes members in labor camps across the United States to win collective dignity at work. They also work to gain fairness in the terms of migration and partner with local workers to strengthen U.S. social movements for racial and economic justice. The website contains information on guestworker rights, news, and current programs.

daodesc.p: National Guestworker Alliance, May 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: National Labor College (NLC), located in Silver Spring, MD, is the only accredited higher education institution in the United States devoted exclusively to educating union members, leaders, and staff. It was established as a training center by the AFL-CIO in 1969 to strengthen union member education and organizing skills. The website contains information on admissions, academic programs, alumni, blogs, conference services and their online campus.

daodesc.p: National Labor College, May 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The National Mobilization Against Sweatshops is a grassroots educational campaign dedicated to ending sweatshop conditions for all working people. It was founded in New York City in 1996. The site includes transcripts of several oral histories of sweatshop workers.

daodesc.p: National Mobilization Against Sweatshops, Sep 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: National Nurses United, with more than 150,000 members from across the country, is the largest union and professional association of registered nurses in America. Founded in December 2009, NNU brought together the California Nurses Association/National Nurses Organizing Committee, United American Nurses, and Massachusetts Nurses Association. Its purpose is to give registered nurses a national voice and organizing power. It is also affiliated with the AFL-CIO.

daodesc.p: National Nurses United, Jan 2009-present

did.unittitle: National Organization of Legal Services Workers (NOLSW), UAW Local 2320

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The National Organization of Legal Services Workers (NOLSW), UAW Local 2320, represents the majority of those who work in federally-funded legal services programs across the United States. The local also represents workers in other types of law offices, various human services programs and other agencies.

dao.ns2:title: National Organization of Legal Services Workers, UAW Local 2320

daodesc.p: National Organization of Legal Services Workers, UAW Local 2320, Jan 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The National Postal Mail Handlers Union, affiliated with the AFL-CIO and LIUNA, is the is the exclusive bargaining agent for 47,000 mail handlers who load, unload, prepare, sort, and containerize mail for the US Postal Service. The website contains news, multimedia, legislatives action alerts, and contract updates.

daodesc.p: National Postal Mail Handlers Union, Apr 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The National Writers Union (NWU) represents freelance writers throughout the United States. It was formed in 1981 during the Writers' Congress held in New York City. In 1981, the NWU affiliated with the United Auto Workers (UAW) as Local 1981. As of 2011, the NWU has over 1,500 members in fifteen locals. The website contains news and chapter information.

daodesc.p: National Writers Union, Dec 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The New York Building Congress, founded in 1921, is a coalition of 400 constituent organizations comprising more than 250,000 skilled trades people and professionals that works to advance economic and infrastructure investment and job creation. The Congress publishes reports and analysis related to building projects in New York City. The Congress also created the New York Building Foundation, which promotes research, education, and philanthropy in the construction industry.

daodesc.p: New York Building Congress, Mar 2009-present

did.unittitle: New York Chapter of the National Writers Union, Local 1981

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The National Writers Union, UAW Local 1981, is a labor union for freelance writers. The NWU advocates for writers' rights and fights to improve the income, contracts and working conditions for all freelance writers, including journalists, book authors, business and technical writers, essayists, poets, playwrights, script writers, writers for the web and campus writers. The NWU, founded in 1981, consists of 16 chapters throughout the country.

dao.ns2:title: New York Chapter of the National Writers Union, Local 1981

daodesc.p: New York Chapter of the National Writers Union, Local 1981, Feb 2009-present

did.unittitle: New York Committee for Occupational Safety and Health

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: New York Committee for Occupational Safety and Health (NYCOSH), founded in 1980, is a non-profit coalition of 200 local unions and more than 400 individual workers, physicians, lawyers and other health and safety activists dedicated to the right of worker safety on the job. NYCOSH operates throughout New York City, Long Island and the Lower Hudson Valley. The website gives information and assistance for those injured on the job and other training and safety resources.

dao.ns2:title: New York Committee for Occupational Safety and Health

daodesc.p: New York Committee for Occupational Safety and Health, Feb 2007-present

did.unittitle: New York Hotel and Motel Trades Council

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Founded in the 1930s, The New York Hotel and Motel Trades Council, AFL-CIO (Hotel Trades Council), is the union of hotel workers in New York City. The Council represents approximately 30,000 non-managerial employees working in all hotel departments, including: housekeeping, public space, dining room, banquet, room service, kitchen, stewarding, bar, mini-bar, audio-visual, front desk, reservations, PBX, bell and door services, concierge, night auditing, laundry, valet, engineering, maintenance, electrical, carpentry, painting, upholstery, business centers, night cleaning, health spas, security, garage, purchasing and receiving, and storeroom in over 300 hotels in the New York City area. It is affiliated with the SEIU, UNITE-HERE, OPEIU, IUOE, IBEW, IUPAT, and USWA.

dao.ns2:title: The New York Hotel and Motel Trades Council

daodesc.p: The New York Hotel and Motel Trades Council, Mar 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: New York Labor History Association (NYLHA) was founded in 1976 by trade unionists, academics, students, archivists, educators, labor editors, attorneys, and retirees, mostly from New York State. NYLHA encourages the study of workers and their organizations and serves as a bridge between past and present labor unionists and academics.

daodesc.p: New York Labor History Association, Apr 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The New York State AFL-CIO, in 1958, is the federation of labor unions in New York State affiliated with the AFL-CIO (American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations).

daodesc.p: New York State AFL-CIO, Sep 2007-present

did.unittitle: New York State Public Employees Federation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Formed in 1978, New York State Public Employees Federation (PEF) is a local white-collar union, representing 55,599 professional, scientific, and technical public employees. PEF also represents employees who work in private-sector jobs and local government agencies including the Albany County Probation Department; Albany Housing Authority; NYS Canal Corporation; National Development and Research Inc; and, Lockport Memorial Hospital. The union publishes The Communicator, a newsletter with a 2007 distribution of 70,000, on a monthly basis

dao.ns2:title: New York State Public Employees Federation

daodesc.p: New York State Public Employees Federation, Nov 2011-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: New York State United Teachers (NYSUT) is a 600,000-member New York state teachers union, affiliated since 2006 with the American Federation of Teachers (AFT), the AFL-CIO, and the National Education Association (NEA). NYSUT is a federation of over 1200 local unions in New York state; lobbies on the local, state and federal level; conducts research; and organizes new members. The website contains a blog, information in benefits, by-laws and contracts, and other resources.

daodesc.p: New York State United Teachers (NYSUT), Feb 2013-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: New York Taxi Workers Alliance, founded in 1998, consists of 15,000 members of yellow taxicab drivers. NYTWA provides legal, health and financial services and improve working conditions through organizing, political and media advocacy, litigation, direct legal services, and access to healthcare. They are part of the Central Labor Council and the International Taxi Workers Alliance.

daodesc.p: New York Taxi Workers Alliance, May 2011-present

did.unittitle: Newspaper Guild of New York, Local 3

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Newspaper Guild of New York, launched in 1934, is an labor union for people in the news and media business, including print, photo, video, and digital journalists, as well as employees in advertising, circulation and other related areas. They represent about 3,000 employees at New York area-based media organizations and their respective bureaus around the nation.

dao.ns2:title: Newspaper Guild of New York, Local 3

daodesc.p: Newspaper Guild of New York, Local 3, Feb 2009-present

did.unittitle: Office and Professional Employees International Union (OPEIU)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Office and Professional Employees International Union is a trade union representing over 110,000 white-collar workers in the public and private sector, including workers in banking and credit unions, insurance, higher education, shipping, hospitals, medical clinics, utilities, transportation, hotels, and administrative offices. Professional organizations and Guilds affiliated with OPEIU are a diverse group that includes physicians, pharmacists, chiropractors, appraisers, podiatrists, clinical social workers, hypnotists, teachers, and helicopter pilots.

did.unittitle: Operative Plasterers' and Cement Masons' International Association of the United States and Canada (OP&CMIA)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Operative Plasterers' and Cement Masons' International Association of the United States and Canada (OPCMIA), founded in 1864, is a trade union of plasterers and cement masons in the construction industry in the United States and Canada. Members of the union finish interior walls and ceilings of buildings and apply plaster on masonry, metal, and wire lath or gypsum. Cement masons are responsible for all concrete construction, including pouring and finishing of slabs, steps, wall tops, curbs and gutters, sidewalks, and paving. The organization is a member union of the AFL–CIO and Canadian Labour Congress.

dao.ns2:title: Operative Plasterers' and Cement Masons' International Association of the United States and Canada (OP&CMIA)

daodesc.p: Operative Plasterers' and Cement Masons' International Association of the United States and Canada (OP&CMIA), Dec 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1970 by twelve employees of the New York City Department of Personnel as the Committee of Personnel Examiners, the Organization of Staff Analysts (OSA) became the official collective bargaining agent for Analysts in the Board of Education in 1985. OSA is a member of, and bargains collectively through, the Municipal Labor Committee. It represents employees of the City of New York in the Analyst title series serving in more than fifty city agencies. The website contains information on benefits, newsletter, and weekly newsline.

daodesc.p: Organization of Staff Analysts, Feb 2013-present

did.unittitle: Organization United for Respect at Walmart (OUR Walmart)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Organization United for Respect at Walmart (OUR Walmart), is an organization which works to make change in labor practices for Walmart associates, established in 2011. The organization works to change policy at Walmart, including the following changes: paying a minimum of $13/hour and make full-time jobs available for Associates who want them; creating dependable, predictable work schedules; providing affordable healthcare; providing every Associate with a policy manual; ensuring equal enforcement of policy and no discrimination; and giving every Associate equal opportunity to succeed and advance in his or her career. The group's website publishes associate stories and provides action alerts.

dao.ns2:title: Organization United for Respect at Walmart (OUR Walmart)

daodesc.p: Organization United for Respect at Walmart (OUR Walmart), Nov 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Professional Aviation Safety Specialists, AFL-CIO (PASS) represents approximately 11,000 Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) and Department of Defense (DoD) employees throughout the United States and in several foreign countries. PASS members include Technical Operations and DoD employees (systems specialists, electronics technicians and computer specialists), Flight Standards and manufacturing aviation safety inspectors, flight inspection pilots, missions specialists and procedures development specialists in Aviation System Standards, and administrative employees in the FAA’s Aviation Registry. In 1977, PASS was formed to provide representation for the FAA’s technician bargaining unit. PASS has grown over the decades and now represents five bargaining units within the FAA and DoD. PASS is dedicated to supporting and sustaining the safety and efficiency of the National Airspace System (NAS) for the flying public.

daodesc.p: Professional Aviation Safety Specialists (PASS), Dec 2009-present

did.unittitle: Professional Staff Congress/City University of New York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Professional Staff Congress is the union that represents more than 20,000 faculty and staff at the City University of New York (CUNY). The union negotiates, administers and enforces collective bargaining agreements; protects the rights of staff through the grievance and arbitration process; engages in political activity on behalf of CUNY and its staff and students; and advocates for the interests of the instructional staff in various forums. It is affiliated with the American Federation of Teachers (AFT), the American Association of University Professors (AAUP), the New York State United Teachers (NYSUT), and the NYC Central Labor Council (CLC).

dao.ns2:title: Professional Staff Congress/City University of New York

daodesc.p: Professional Staff Congress/City University of New York, Sep 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Progressive Librarians Guild, founded in 1990, is a forum for open exchange of radical views on library issues. The Guild conducts campaigns to support progressive and democratic library activities; supports activist librarians as they work to effect changes in their own libraries and communities; bridges the gaps between school, public, academic and special libraries, and between public and technical services; encourages debate about prevailing management strategies adopted directly from the business world and to propose democratic forms of library administration; considers the impact of technological change in the library workplace; monitors the professional ethics of librarianship from a perspective of social responsibility; and facilitates contacts between progressive librarians and other professional and scholarly groups in the record keeping field. The Guild publishes a journal, the Progressive Librarian.

daodesc.p: Progressive Librarians Guild, Nov 2008-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Radicals at Work is a network of young activists and radicals involved in workers’ movements. The network works to build a stronger movement from the bottom-up. The website informs and educates on issues in the workers’ movement. The website has not been updated since mid-2010.

daodesc.p: Radicals at Work, Apr 2011-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Remember the Triangle Fire Coalition, established for the centennial of the Triangle Shirtwaist factory fire, works to build of a public art memorial to honor the legacy of the Triangle factory workers and spread awareness of the fire through education and activism. The website contains information on the memorial design competition, an open archive of digitized material on the fire, labor activism in the early twentieth century, and the victims. The website also contains a names map, resources, and information about their centennial commemoration.

daodesc.p: Remember the Triangle Fire Coalition, Sep 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Restaurant Opportunities Centers United (ROC-United), founded in 2001, is a national coalition of restaurant workers' organizations. It works to is to improve wages and working conditions for the nation’s low-wage restaurant workforce. ROC-United does extensive statistical research to understand the labor market in ROC-United regions.

daodesc.p: Restaurant Opportunities Centers United, Jul 2011-present

did.unittitle: Retail, Wholesale, and Department Store Union. Local 1-S Department Store Workers Union

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Local 1-S is a local branch of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union/UFCW (RWDSU), which represents Macy’s workers in the United States and 3,500 employees at the Macy’s department store in Herald Square, Manhattan. The union works to protect Macy's employees' right to the fair wages and benefits that allow them to support themselves and their families.

dao.ns2:title: Retail, Wholesale, and Department Store Union. Local 1-S Department Store Workers Union

daodesc.p: Retail, Wholesale, and Department Store Union. Local 1-S Department Store Workers Union, Mar 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The website contains information on the merger in 2012 of the Screen Actors Guild (SAG) and American Federation of Television and Radio Artists (AFTRA). It contains news related to the merger, events, frequently asked questions, and a page on merger materials.

daodesc.p: SAG-AFTRA, Feb 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Screen Actors Guild (SAG), established in 1993, is an American labor union representing over 200,000 film and television performers worldwide. According to SAG's Mission Statement, the Guild seeks to: negotiate and enforce collective bargaining agreements that establish equitable levels of compensation, benefits, and working conditions for its performers; collect compensation for exploitation of recorded performances by its members, and provide protection against unauthorized use of those performances; and preserve and expand work opportunities for its members. SAG merged with AFTRA in March 2012.

daodesc.p: Screen Actors Guild (SAG), Dec 2009-Sep 2012

did.unittitle: Screen Actors Guild, New York Branch

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The New York Branch of the Screen Actors Guild is one of twenty branches nationwide representing actors working in motion pictures, television, commercials, industrials, video games, Internet and all new media formats. The Guild exists to enhance actors working conditions, compensation and benefits and to be a powerful, unified voice on behalf of artists rights.

dao.ns2:title: Screen Actors Guild, New York Branch

daodesc.p: Screen Actors Guild, New York Branch, Mar 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1938, The Seafarers International Union, Atlantic, Gulf, Lakes and Inland Waters District/NMU, AFL-CIO, represents unlicensed United States merchant mariners sailing aboard U.S.-flag vessels in the deep sea, Great Lakes and inland trades. The union also represents licensed U.S. mariners in the Great Lakes and inland sectors. The website contains information on their training center, the Paul Hall Center for Maritime Training and Education, news, and stories.

daodesc.p: Seafarers International Union, Apr 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Service Employees International Union (SEIU), founded in 1921, is a labor union representing about 1.8 million workers in over 100 occupations in the United States (including Puerto Rico), and Canada. SEIU is focused on organizing workers in three sectors: health care (over half of members work in the health care field), including hospital, home care and nursing home workers; public services (local and state government employees); and, property services (including janitors, security officers and food service workers). It is affiliated with the Change to Win Federation and the Canadian Labour Congress.

daodesc.p: Service Employees International Union (SEIU), Dec 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Sheet Metal Workers International Association, founded in 1888, is a trade union of skilled metal workers who perform architectural sheet metal work, fabricate and install heating and air conditioning work, shipbuilding, appliance construction, heater and boiler construction, precision and specialty parts manufacture, and a variety of other jobs involving sheet metal. The Sheet Metal Workers International Association represents about 150,000 members in 185 local unions in the United States and Canada.

daodesc.p: Sheet Metal Workers International Association (SMWIA) , Dec 2009-present

did.unittitle: Sheet Metal Workers International Association, Local 137

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The mission of the Sheet Metal Workers International Association, Local Union No. 137 is to organize, educate, and represent all workers in associated crafts in the New York region. The purpose of the Union is to represent all members in their fight to improve benefits, wages, and safe working conditions.

dao.ns2:title: Sheet Metal Workers International Association, Local 137

daodesc.p: Sheet Metal Workers International Association, Local 137, Mar 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1965, Social Service Employees Union Local 371 is part of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees AFL-CIO (AFSCME), which represents workers employed by New York City in social service professions.

daodesc.p: Social Service Employees Union Local 371, Sep 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Southwest Workers Union, launched in May of 1988 in Hondo, Texas, is an organization of low-income workers and families, community residents, and youth, united in the struggle for worker rights, environmental justice and community empowerment. The union organizes 2500 members. The website contains resources and news.

daodesc.p: Southwest Workers Union, Jul 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Starbucks Workers Union is an organization of employees at Starbucks (a coffee chain) united for a living wage, secure work hours, and respect on the job. They are affiliated with the Industrial Workers of the World.

daodesc.p: Starbucks Workers Union (IWW), Sep 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: On August 13, 2008, over 135 members of Bakery, Confectionery, Tobacco Workers and Grain Millers International Union Local 50, employed at the Stella D'Oro plant in the Bronx, went on strike citing proposed pay and benefit cuts, and later picketed the company's attempt to bring in replacement workers.In early September 2010, a 2 to 1 ruling by the National Labor Relations Board affirmed the June 2009 decision of an administrative law judge that Stella D'oro violated federal labor law by refusing to furnish detailed financial statements to the workers' union to support claims of needing contract concessions to survive. The factory closed in October 2009. This website was a support page for the strike which posted news and other information.

daodesc.p: Stella Doro Strike 2008, Aug 2009-May 2011

did.unittitle: Street Vendors Mobilizing and Organizing in Solidarity

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Vendedoras Ambulantes Movilizando y Organizando en Solidaridad (VAMOS Unidos or Street Vendors Mobilizing and Organizing in Solidarity) is a Bronx based social justice organization, founded in 2007 by low income Latino/Latina street vendors. The organization works to organize Latino immigrants, for economic and racial justice, immigrant rights, and police accountability. The website contains information on provided services, news, photos, and videos.

dao.ns2:title: Street Vendors Mobilizing and Organizing in Solidarity

daodesc.p: Street Vendors Mobilizing and Organizing in Solidarity, May 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Teamsters for a Democratic Union, founded in 1976, is a rank-and-file union democracy movement organizing to reform the International Brotherhood of Teamsters (IBT). TDU was created out of the merger of the Professional Drivers Council (PROD) and TDU in 1979. They represent truck drivers, dock workers, warehouse workers, and clericals.

daodesc.p: Teamsters for a Democratic Union, Feb 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The WAGE Project (Women Are Getting Even) is an organization that was established to end discrimination against women in the American workplace. The project offers resources and workshops to help close the wage gap. WAGE is led by Evelyn F. Murphy, author of Getting Even: Why Women Don't Get Paid Like Men and What To Do About It. Dr. Murphy is a Ph.D. economist, former Lt. Governor of Massachusetts; and by Annie Houle, National Director of Campus and Community Initiatives.

daodesc.p: The Wage Project, Nov 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Transport Workers Union of America (TWU) is a labor union that was founded in 1934 by subway workers in New York City. Today, the TWU has four divisions: Railroad; Gaming; Airline; Transit; and Utility, University and Service. The Union has 114 autonomous locals representing over 200,000 members and retirees in 22 states around the country. The TWU is a member of the AFL-CIO and the International Transport Workers Federation (ITF).

daodesc.p: Transport Workers Union of America, Sep 2007-present

did.unittitle: Transport Workers Union of America, Local 100

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Local 100 is a local of the Transport Workers Union of America. The Local primarily represents workers in the New York City public transportation system and at some private bus lines serving the New York City metropolitan area.

dao.ns2:title: Transport Workers Union of America, Local 100

daodesc.p: Transport Workers Union of America, Local 100, Sep 2007-present

did.unittitle: UFT Alliance of Charter Teachers and Staff

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The United Federation of Teachers Alliance of Charter Teachers and Staff (UFT ACTS ) is a community of charter school employees organized by the UFT, which is a local union chapter of the American Federation of Teachers (AFT) and represents public school teachers, some private school teachers and other professionals in New York City. The UFT is affiliated with the statewide New York State United Teachers (NYSUT) and the national American Federation of Teachers (AFT). The UFT represents 13 charter schools in New York City.

dao.ns2:title: UFT Alliance of Charter Teachers and Staff

daodesc.p: UFT Alliance of Charter Teachers and Staff, Nov 2011-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Union Communication Services, Inc. was founded in 1981 by David Prosten, a former publications and public relations director and staffer for several national unions. The website publishes and distributes steward advice, labor news, graphics and books that help progressive union leaders rally their members and build their unions. The organization is used by over 2000 unions in the United States and Canada. The website also contains a listing of every union website.

daodesc.p: Union Communications Services, Dec 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Union Democracy Review is the bi-monthly publication of the Association for Union Democracy.

daodesc.p: Union Democracy Review, Feb 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Union Jobs Clearinghouse, is a site for posting the open staffing and trades positions in unions and allied organizations in the U.S. and throughout the world that are currently accepting applications.

daodesc.p: Union Jobs Clearinghouse, Sep 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Union Label and Service Trades Department, AFL-CIO, was founded in 1909 to promote the products and services produced in America by union members, specifically products and services identified by a union label, shop card, store card and service button. The website contains information on current boycotts, personal stories, news, a photo gallery, and their publication, the Label Letter.

daodesc.p: Union Label, May 2012-present

did.unittitle: Union of Clerical, Administrative and Technical Staff at NYU, Local 3882, NYSUT, AFT, AFL-CIO

scopecontent.p: Union of Clerical, Administrative & Technical Staff, Local 3882, NYSUT, AFT, AFL-CIO (UCATS), founded in 1978, is a labor union that represents over 1500 clerical, administrative, and technical staff at New York University. They are affiliated with the American Federation of Teachers and were formerly known as the United Staff Association of NYU.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Union Songs is an online collection of lyrics, discography, bibliography, and filmography of songs related to the labor movement. The website contains links to union music and other cultural sites. The coverage is international, but the coverage of Australia is extensive. The website contains over 770 songs and poems and over 300 authors.

daodesc.p: Union Songs, Aug 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: UnionBook is a social networking website for trade unionists and a project of LabourStart. The website has a microblogging feature called the Wire.

daodesc.p: UnionBook, Jul 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: UNITE HERE is the merger of two labor unions, the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees (UNITE) and the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International Union (HERE). UNITE HERE, founded in 2004, is a labor union in the United States and Canada with more than 265,000 active members. The union's members work predominantly in the hotel, food service, laundry, warehouse, and casino gaming industries. It is currently affiliated with the AFL-CIO.

daodesc.p: Unite Here (Organization), Sep 2007-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: United American Nurses (UAN) was an American union affiliated with the AFL-CIO. Founded in 1999 and dissolved in 2009, it represented registered nurses (RNs). In 2009, UAN merged with the California Nurses Association/National Nurses Organizing Committee and Massachusetts Nurses Association to form National Nurses United.

daodesc.p: United American Nurses (UAN), Dec 2009-Sep 2011

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The United Association for Labor Education (UALE), created out of a merger between the Workers’ Education Local 189 and the University and College Labor Education Association in 2000, is an international association for post-secondary, community, union and associated labor educators. The UALE co-publishes the Labor Studies Journal with West Virginia University.

daodesc.p: United Association for Labor Education, Aug 2009-present

did.unittitle: United Association of Journeymen and Apprentices of the Plumbing and Pipe Fitting Industry of the United States and Canada (UA)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1889, the United Association of Journeymen and Apprentices of the Plumbing, Pipefitting and Sprinkler Fitting Industry of the United States and Canada, (United Association, UA) is a trade union of journeymen and apprentices of the plumbing, pipefitting, and sprinkler fitting industry of the United States and Canada. The members fabricate, install, and service piping systems. There are approximately 340,000 highly-skilled United Association members who belong to over 300 individual local unions across North America.

dao.ns2:title: United Association of Journeymen and Apprentices of the Plumbing and Pipe Fitting Industry of the United States and Canada (UA)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America (UBC), founded in 1881, is a building trade union with approximately a half-million members in the construction and wood-products industries. UBC members consist of carpenters, millwrights, interior systems and framing and residential carpenters, floor coverers, pile drivers, lathers, and millworkers and cabinetmakers. The website contains information on training programs, partnership programs, and legislative issues.

daodesc.p: United Brotherhood of Carpenters, Apr 2012-present

did.unittitle: United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America, Cabinetmakers Local 2090

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The United Brotherhood of Carpenters Shop and Industrial Local 2790 was formed in August 2011, from the dissolution of the Architectural Woodworkers Local 2090 and Industrial Local 2870. UBC Local Union 2790 is a specialty trade union that represents carpenters, industrial shop workers, architectural woodworkers, millworkers, finish carpenters, wood finishers, cabinet installers, trim carpenters, architectural metal workers, and cabinetmakers throughout the five boroughs of New York City; as well as Long Island, New Jersey, and Westchester County. Local 2790 is part of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters & Joiners of America, and the New York City District Council of Carpenters.

daodesc.p: United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America, Cabinetmakers Local 2090, Mar 2009-present

did.unittitle: United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America (UE)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America or the Rank-and-File Union (UE) is a national union representing some 35,000 workers in a wide variety of manufacturing, public sector and private non-profit sector jobs. UE is an independent union (not affiliated with the AFL-CIO). Members work in electrical manufacturing, metalworking and plastics as plastic injection molders, tool and die makers, sheet metal workers, truck drivers, warehouse workers, and custodians. The website contains a blog, information for workers and unions, and political action campaigns.

dao.ns2:title: United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America (UE)

daodesc.p: United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America (UE) , May 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1962 by Cesar Chavez, the United Farm Workers of America represents farm workers in the United States. Formed from the merger of the Agricultural Workers Organizing Committee and the National Farm Workers Association, it is affiliated with the Change to Win Federation.

daodesc.p: United Farm Workers of America, Dec 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The United Federation of Teachers (Local 2 of the American Federation of Teachers) represents more than 200,000 people, and is the sole bargaining agent for most of the non-supervisory educators who work in the New York City public schools. It represents approximately 74,000 teachers and 17,000 classroom paraprofessionals, along with school secretaries, attendance teachers, guidance counselors, psychologists, social workers, education evaluators, nurses, laboratory technicians, adult education teachers and 32,000 retired members. The UFT also represents teachers and other employees of some private educational institutions. The allied Federation of Nurses/UFT represents some 2,500 registered nurses of the New York City Visiting Nurse Service and several private New York City hospitals and health care institutions. The union led a successful organizing drive to gain collective-bargaining rights for 28,000 New York City home child-care providers in 2007.

daodesc.p: United Federation of Teachers, Sep 2007-present

did.unittitle: United Food and Commercial Workers International Union (UFCW)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The United Food and Commercial Workers International Union, founded in 1979, is a labor union representing approximately 1.3 million workers in the United States and Canada in many industries, including agriculture, health care, meatpacking, poultry and food processing, manufacturing, textile, chemical trades, and retail food. It is affiliated with the Change to Win Coalition.

dao.ns2:title: United Food and Commercial Workers International Union (UFCW)

daodesc.p: United Food and Commercial Workers International Union (UFCW), Dec 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1890, The United Mine Workers of America is a North American labor union which has represented coal miners and coal technicians. Today, the Union also represents health care workers, truck drivers, manufacturing workers and public employees in the United States and Canada.

daodesc.p: United Mine Workers of America (UMWA) , Dec 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: United Scenic Artists [founded in 1897 as the United Scenic Artists Association], Local USA 829, is a labor union and professional association of Designers, Artists and Craftspeople organized to protect craft standards, working conditions and wages for the entertainment and decorative arts industries. The members of Local USA 829 are Artists and Designers working in film, theatre, opera, ballet, television, industrial shows, commercials and exhibitions.

daodesc.p: United Scenic Artists, Local 829, Jun 2013-present

did.unittitle: United Steel, Paper and Forestry, Rubber, Manufacturing, Energy, Allied Industrial and Service Workers International Union (USW)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The United Steel, Paper and Forestry, Rubber, Manufacturing, Energy, Allied Industrial and Service Workers International Union (United Steelworkers or USW), founded in 1942, is the largest industrial labor union in North America, with 705,000 members. Headquartered in Pittsburgh, U.S., the United Steelworkers represents workers in the United States, Canada and the Caribbean. The United Steelworkers represent workers in a diverse range of industries, including primary and fabricated metals, chemicals, glass, rubber, heavy-duty conveyor belting, tires, transportation, utilities, container industries, pharmaceuticals, call centers and health care.

dao.ns2:title: United Steel, Paper and forestry, Rubber, Manufacturing, Energy, Allied Industrial and Service Workers International Union (USW)

daodesc.p: United Steel, Paper and forestry, Rubber, Manufacturing, Energy, Allied Industrial and Service Workers International Union (USW), Dec 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The United Transportation Union (UTU), founded in 1969, is a transportation labor union representing about 125,000 active and retired railroad, bus, mass transit, and airline workers in the United States with more than 600 locals. It is headquartered in Cleveland, OH and affiliated with the AFL-CIO.

daodesc.p: United Transportation Union (UTU), Dec 2009-present

did.unittitle: United Union of Roofers, Waterproofers and Allied Workers (Roofers and Waterproofers)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The United Union of Roofers, Waterproofers and Allied Workers, founded in 1903, has approximately 22,000 members organized into nine district councils across the United States. Members participate in the National Roofing Industry Supplemental Pension, Multi-trade Organizing Volunteer Education program (MOVE), health and safety programs, as well as training and apprenticeship opportunities, and cooperative labor-management research and education efforts.

dao.ns2:title: United Union of Roofers, Waterproofers and Allied Workers

daodesc.p: United Union of Roofers, Waterproofers and Allied Workers, Dec 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The United Workers, founded in 2002 by homeless day laborers in Baltimore, is a human rights organization led by low-wage workers. They fight for fair development, which respects human rights, maximizes public benefits, and is sustainable. The organization focuses on understanding the root causes of poverty and organizing around universal human rights. They work for change through conferences and campaigns, including The Living Wages at Camden Yards Campaign.

daodesc.p: United Workers, May 2011-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Union Producers and Programmers Network Online (UPPNET) provided links to television and radio programs for organized labor and working people, campaigned to make labor media a priority within the labor movement, and published the online UPPNET Newsletter. The site has been inactive since 2007.

daodesc.p: UPPNET , Aug 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The United States Federation of Worker Cooperatives, founded in 2004, is a national grassroots membership organization of and for worker cooperatives, democratic workplaces, and organizations that support the growth and development of worker cooperatives. The organization offers resources and education for worker cooperatives.

daodesc.p: US Federation of Worker Cooperatives, Nov 2011-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: U.S. Labor Against the War, was founded in 2003 in opposition to the Iraq War, Its principles include: to advocate, educate and mobilize in the US labor movement for: a just foreign policy that will bring genuine security and prosperity to working people and an end to U.S. occupation of foreign countries, replaced by the reconstruction of war-devastated nations with the full support of the international community and the full participation and decision-making power of affected peoples. The organization also supports the broader social justice ideals associated with the labor movement.

daodesc.p: US Labor Against the War, Sep 2007-present

did.unittitle: Utility Workers Union of America, Local 1-2

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Local 1-2 of the Utility Workers Union of America evolved out of the Utility Workers Organizing Committee (UWOC) established by the Congress of Industrial Organizations (CIO) in 1938. In 1946, with more than 180 locals organized nationwide, the UWOC transformed itself into the Utility Workers Union of America, CIO. Local 1-2 represents New York area with members working in the electric, gas, water, and nuclear industries across the United States.

dao.ns2:title: Utility Workers Union of America, Local 1-2

daodesc.p: Utility Workers Union of America, Local 1-2, Feb 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Utility Workers Union of America, AFL-CIO (UWUA), is a union with over 50,000 members working in the electric, gas, water, and nuclear industries across the United States. It represents utility workers in municipal, as well as publicly traded utilities. Fields include power generation (power plants), power distribution (transmission and distribution), call/service center employees, as well as natural gas and water utilities.

daodesc.p: Utility Workers Union of America (UWUA), Dec 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Vermont Workers’ Center was founded in 1996 by a group of low-income workers in Central Vermont. The Vermont Workers' Center is a democratic, member-run organization dedicated to organizing for workers' rights and living wages for all Vermonters. They organize rallies, public hearings, forums, publicizing peoples' stories, and taking direct action, we support workers throughout the state who are trying to improve their wages, benefits, rights on the job, working conditions and their communities. It is affiliated with Jobs for Justice and Grassroots Global Justice.

daodesc.p: Vermont Workers' Center, May 2011-present

did.unittitle: Wobbly City: Newsletter of the NYC Branch (IWW)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Wobbly City is the official blog of the New York City General Membership Branch (GMB) of the Industrial Workers of the World (IWW).

dao.ns2:title: Wobbly City: Newsletter of the NYC Branch (IWW)

daodesc.p: Wobbly City: Newsletter of the NYC Branch (IWW) , Jul 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Women on the Job (WOJ) was founded in 1981 as a private, not-for-profit advocacy organization dedicated to achieving women’s equality in the workplace on Long Island. WOJ was a project of Resources for Program Development, Inc. (RPD), which had been established with funding from the North Shore Unitarian Universalist Society VEATCH Program. The WOJ program was initiated in October 1981 by co-founders Lillian McCormick and Charlotte Shapiro. Its mission was to foster equal employment opportunities for women and combat workplace discrimination against women in Long Island communities.

daodesc.p: Women on the Job, Mar 2009-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Worker’s Stand for America is the website of a national worker’s rally that took place August 11, 2012 in Philadelphia. The rally worked to change the political focus toward job creation, worker’s rights, and education reform. The website contains a video of the entire rally, news and press releases, and their Second Bill of Rights, which is a petition that calls for the right to full employment and a living wage; the right to full participation in the electoral process; right to a voice at work, the right to quality education; and the right to a secure, healthy future.

daodesc.p: Workers Stand for America, Aug 2012-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Working America, founded in 2003, is an allied organization of the AFL-CIO which works to build alliances among non-union working people. Working America is a nonpartisan, non-profit organization which provides workers who are not union members input into the policies, goals, and legislative efforts of the AFL-CIO. It also recruits people to help with letter-writing campaigns, canvassing, and other activities to promote causes important to the labor federation.

daodesc.p: Working America, Oct 2011-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Working-Class Perspectives (founded July, 2008) is the blog of the Center for Working-Class Studies at Youngstown State University (Ohio). Working-Class Perspectives offers weekly commentaries on current issues related to working-class people and communities. Contributors discuss a variety of issues, from what class means to how it intersects with race and gender to how class is shaping American politics.

daodesc.p: Working-Class Perspectives, Jan 2010-present

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: WorkingLife.org is the blog of the Labor Research Association (LRA), which was founded in 1927 to collect data on labor for trade unions and publish that information, statistics, and related news, and was for many years informally associated with the Communist Party USA. The Labor Research Association is a New York City-based non-profit research and advocacy organization that provides research and educational services for trade unions. LRA's work is overseen by a Board of Directors composed of union leaders and others involved in the labor movement. The website fosters discussion on work, the economy, and labor.

daodesc.p: Working Life, Sep 2007-present

did.unittitle: Writers Guild of America, East Inc. (WGAE)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Writers Guild of America, East, founded in 1951, is a labor union of thousands of professionals who are the primary creators of what is seen or heard on television and film in the U.S., as well as digital media content. The Guild negotiates contracts, make sure on-screen credits are fair and accurate, and provides education and training for members. The Writers Guild of America, East is affiliated with the Writers Guild of America, West. Together the guilds administer the Writers Guild of America Awards. It is an affiliate of both the International Federation of Journalists and the International Affiliation of Writers Guilds, as well as an affiliate of the AFL-CIO.
